component.name: rabbitmq
component.title: RabbitMQ
component.description: The rabbitmq component allows you produce and consume messages from RabbitMQ instances.
component.label: messaging

addresses.label: common
addresses.description: If this option is set, camel-rabbitmq will try to create connection based on the setting of option addresses. The addresses value is a string which looks like server1:12345, server2:12345

autoDelete.label: common
autoDelete.description: If it is true, the exchange will be deleted when it is no longer in use

connectionFactory.label: common
connectionFactory.description: To use a custom RabbitMQ connection factory. When this option is set, all connection options (connectionTimeout, requestedChannelMax...) set on URI are not used

deadLetterExchange.label: common
deadLetterExchange.description: The name of the dead letter exchange

deadLetterExchangeType.label: common
deadLetterExchangeType.description: The type of the dead letter exchange

deadLetterQueue.label: common
deadLetterQueue.description: The name of the dead letter queue

deadLetterRoutingKey.label: common
deadLetterRoutingKey.description: The routing key for the dead letter exchange

declare.label: common
declare.description: If the option is true, camel declare the exchange and queue name and bind them together. If the option is false, camel won't declare the exchange and queue name on the server.

durable.label: common
durable.description: If we are declaring a durable exchange (the exchange will survive a server restart)

exclusive.label: common
exclusive.description: Exclusive queues may only be accessed by the current connection, and are deleted when that connection closes.

hostname.label: common
hostname.description: The hostname of the running RabbitMQ instance or cluster.

passive.label: common
passive.description: Passive queues depend on the queue already to be available at RabbitMQ.

portNumber.label: common
portNumber.description: Port number for the host with the running rabbitmq instance or cluster.

skipExchangeDeclare.label: common
skipExchangeDeclare.description: This can be used if we need to declare the queue but not the exchange

skipQueueBind.label: common
skipQueueBind.description: If true the queue will not be bound to the exchange after declaring it

skipQueueDeclare.label: common
skipQueueDeclare.description: If true the producer will not declare and bind a queue. This can be used for directing messages via an existing routing key.

autoAck.label: consumer
autoAck.description: If messages should be auto acknowledged

bridgeErrorHandler.label: consumer
bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

exclusiveConsumer.label: consumer
exclusiveConsumer.description: Request exclusive access to the queue (meaning only this consumer can access the queue). This is useful when you want a long-lived shared queue to be temporarily accessible by just one consumer.

prefetchCount.label: consumer
prefetchCount.description: The maximum number of messages that the server will deliver, 0 if unlimited. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchEnabled.label: consumer
prefetchEnabled.description: Enables the quality of service on the RabbitMQConsumer side. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchGlobal.label: consumer
prefetchGlobal.description: If the settings should be applied to the entire channel rather than each consumer You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchSize.label: consumer
prefetchSize.description: The maximum amount of content (measured in octets) that the server will deliver, 0 if unlimited. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

threadPoolSize.label: consumer,advanced
threadPoolSize.description: The consumer uses a Thread Pool Executor with a fixed number of threads. This setting allows you to set that number of threads.

allowNullHeaders.label: producer
allowNullHeaders.description: Allow pass null values to header

channelPoolMaxSize.label: producer
channelPoolMaxSize.description: Get maximum number of opened channel in pool

channelPoolMaxWait.label: producer
channelPoolMaxWait.description: Set the maximum number of milliseconds to wait for a channel from the pool

guaranteedDeliveries.label: producer
guaranteedDeliveries.description: When true, an exception will be thrown when the message cannot be delivered (basic.return) and the message is marked as mandatory. PublisherAcknowledgement will also be activated in this case. See also publisher acknowledgements - When will messages be confirmed.

immediate.label: producer
immediate.description: This flag tells the server how to react if the message cannot be routed to a queue consumer immediately. If this flag is set, the server will return an undeliverable message with a Return method. If this flag is zero, the server will queue the message, but with no guarantee that it will ever be consumed. If the header is present rabbitmq.IMMEDIATE it will override this option.

lazyStartProducer.label: producer
lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

mandatory.label: producer
mandatory.description: This flag tells the server how to react if the message cannot be routed to a queue. If this flag is set, the server will return an unroutable message with a Return method. If this flag is zero, the server silently drops the message. If the header is present rabbitmq.MANDATORY it will override this option.

publisherAcknowledgements.label: producer
publisherAcknowledgements.description: When true, the message will be published with publisher acknowledgements turned on

publisherAcknowledgementsTimeout.label: producer
publisherAcknowledgementsTimeout.description: The amount of time in milliseconds to wait for a basic.ack response from RabbitMQ server

args.label: advanced
args.description: Specify arguments for configuring the different RabbitMQ concepts, a different prefix is required for each: Exchange: arg.exchange. Queue: arg.queue. Binding: arg.binding. For example to declare a queue with message ttl argument: http://localhost:5672/exchange/queueargs=arg.queue.x-message-ttl=60000

autoDetectConnectionFactory.label: advanced
autoDetectConnectionFactory.description: Whether to auto-detect looking up RabbitMQ connection factory from the registry. When enabled and a single instance of the connection factory is found then it will be used. An explicit connection factory can be configured on the component or endpoint level which takes precedence.

automaticRecoveryEnabled.label: advanced
automaticRecoveryEnabled.description: Enables connection automatic recovery (uses connection implementation that performs automatic recovery when connection shutdown is not initiated by the application)

basicPropertyBinding.label: advanced
basicPropertyBinding.description: Whether the component should use basic property binding (Camel 2.x) or the newer property binding with additional capabilities

clientProperties.label: advanced
clientProperties.description: Connection client properties (client info used in negotiating with the server)

networkRecoveryInterval.label: advanced
networkRecoveryInterval.description: Network recovery interval in milliseconds (interval used when recovering from network failure)

requestedChannelMax.label: advanced
requestedChannelMax.description: Connection requested channel max (max number of channels offered)

requestedFrameMax.label: advanced
requestedFrameMax.description: Connection requested frame max (max size of frame offered)

requestedHeartbeat.label: advanced
requestedHeartbeat.description: Connection requested heartbeat (heart-beat in seconds offered)

requestTimeout.label: advanced
requestTimeout.description: Set timeout for waiting for a reply when using the InOut Exchange Pattern (in milliseconds)

topologyRecoveryEnabled.label: advanced
topologyRecoveryEnabled.description: Enables connection topology recovery (should topology recovery be performed)

transferException.label: advanced
transferException.description: When true and an inOut Exchange failed on the consumer side send the caused Exception back in the response

sslProtocol.label: security
sslProtocol.description: Enables SSL on connection, accepted value are true, TLS and 'SSLv3

trustManager.label: security
trustManager.description: Configure SSL trust manager, SSL should be enabled for this option to be effective

username.label: security
username.description: Username in case of authenticated access

exchangeName.description: The exchange name determines which exchange produced messages will sent to. In the case of consumers, the exchange name determines which exchange the queue will bind to.

addresses.label: common
addresses.description: If this option is set, camel-rabbitmq will try to create connection based on the setting of option addresses. The addresses value is a string which looks like server1:12345, server2:12345

autoDelete.label: common
autoDelete.description: If it is true, the exchange will be deleted when it is no longer in use

automaticRecoveryEnabled.label: common
automaticRecoveryEnabled.description: Enables connection automatic recovery (uses connection implementation that performs automatic recovery when existing connection has failures)

connectionFactory.label: common
connectionFactory.description: To use a custom RabbitMQ connection factory. When this option is set, all connection options (connectionTimeout, requestedChannelMax...) set on URI are not used

deadLetterExchange.label: common
deadLetterExchange.description: The name of the dead letter exchange

deadLetterExchangeType.label: common
deadLetterExchangeType.description: The type of the dead letter exchange

deadLetterQueue.label: common
deadLetterQueue.description: The name of the dead letter queue

deadLetterRoutingKey.label: common
deadLetterRoutingKey.description: The routing key for the dead letter exchange

declare.label: common
declare.description: If the option is true, camel declare the exchange and queue name and bind them together. If the option is false, camel won't declare the exchange and queue name on the server.

durable.label: common
durable.description: If we are declaring a durable exchange (the exchange will survive a server restart)

exchangeType.label: common
exchangeType.description: The exchange type such as direct or topic.

exclusive.label: common
exclusive.description: Exclusive queues may only be accessed by the current connection, and are deleted when that connection closes.

hostname.label: common
hostname.description: The hostname of the running rabbitmq instance or cluster.

passive.label: common
passive.description: Passive queues depend on the queue already to be available at RabbitMQ.

portNumber.label: common
portNumber.description: Port number for the host with the running rabbitmq instance or cluster. Default value is 5672.

queue.label: common
queue.description: The queue to receive messages from

routingKey.label: common
routingKey.description: The routing key to use when binding a consumer queue to the exchange. For producer routing keys, you set the header rabbitmq.ROUTING_KEY.

skipExchangeDeclare.label: common
skipExchangeDeclare.description: This can be used if we need to declare the queue but not the exchange

skipQueueBind.label: common
skipQueueBind.description: If true the queue will not be bound to the exchange after declaring it

skipQueueDeclare.label: common
skipQueueDeclare.description: If true the producer will not declare and bind a queue. This can be used for directing messages via an existing routing key.

autoAck.label: consumer
autoAck.description: If messages should be auto acknowledged

bridgeErrorHandler.label: consumer
bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

concurrentConsumers.label: consumer
concurrentConsumers.description: Number of concurrent consumers when consuming from broker. (eg similar as to the same option for the JMS component).

consumerTag.label: consumer
consumerTag.description: Specify a client-generated consumer tag to establish context when invoking the consume operation

exclusiveConsumer.label: consumer
exclusiveConsumer.description: Request exclusive access to the queue (meaning only this consumer can access the queue). This is useful when you want a long-lived shared queue to be temporarily accessible by just one consumer.

prefetchCount.label: consumer
prefetchCount.description: The maximum number of messages that the server will deliver, 0 if unlimited. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchEnabled.label: consumer
prefetchEnabled.description: Enables the quality of service on the RabbitMQConsumer side. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchGlobal.label: consumer
prefetchGlobal.description: If the settings should be applied to the entire channel rather than each consumer You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

prefetchSize.label: consumer
prefetchSize.description: The maximum amount of content (measured in octets) that the server will deliver, 0 if unlimited. You need to specify the option of prefetchSize, prefetchCount, prefetchGlobal at the same time

exceptionHandler.label: consumer,advanced
exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

exchangePattern.label: consumer,advanced
exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange.

threadPoolSize.label: consumer,advanced
threadPoolSize.description: The consumer uses a Thread Pool Executor with a fixed number of threads. This setting allows you to set that number of threads.

allowCustomHeaders.label: producer
allowCustomHeaders.description: Allow pass custom values to header

allowNullHeaders.label: producer
allowNullHeaders.description: Allow pass null values to header

bridgeEndpoint.label: producer
bridgeEndpoint.description: If the bridgeEndpoint is true, the producer will ignore the message header of rabbitmq.EXCHANGE_NAME and rabbitmq.ROUTING_KEY

channelPoolMaxSize.label: producer
channelPoolMaxSize.description: Get maximum number of opened channel in pool

channelPoolMaxWait.label: producer
channelPoolMaxWait.description: Set the maximum number of milliseconds to wait for a channel from the pool

guaranteedDeliveries.label: producer
guaranteedDeliveries.description: When true, an exception will be thrown when the message cannot be delivered (basic.return) and the message is marked as mandatory. PublisherAcknowledgement will also be activated in this case. See also publisher acknowledgements - When will messages be confirmed.

immediate.label: producer
immediate.description: This flag tells the server how to react if the message cannot be routed to a queue consumer immediately. If this flag is set, the server will return an undeliverable message with a Return method. If this flag is zero, the server will queue the message, but with no guarantee that it will ever be consumed. If the header is present rabbitmq.IMMEDIATE it will override this option.

lazyStartProducer.label: producer
lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

mandatory.label: producer
mandatory.description: This flag tells the server how to react if the message cannot be routed to a queue. If this flag is set, the server will return an unroutable message with a Return method. If this flag is zero, the server silently drops the message. If the header is present rabbitmq.MANDATORY it will override this option.

publisherAcknowledgements.label: producer
publisherAcknowledgements.description: When true, the message will be published with publisher acknowledgements turned on

publisherAcknowledgementsTimeout.label: producer
publisherAcknowledgementsTimeout.description: The amount of time in milliseconds to wait for a basic.ack response from RabbitMQ server

args.label: advanced
args.description: Specify arguments for configuring the different RabbitMQ concepts, a different prefix is required for each: Exchange: arg.exchange. Queue: arg.queue. Binding: arg.binding. For example to declare a queue with message ttl argument: http://localhost:5672/exchange/queueargs=arg.queue.x-message-ttl=60000

basicPropertyBinding.label: advanced
basicPropertyBinding.description: Whether the endpoint should use basic property binding (Camel 2.x) or the newer property binding with additional capabilities

clientProperties.label: advanced
clientProperties.description: Connection client properties (client info used in negotiating with the server)

networkRecoveryInterval.label: advanced
networkRecoveryInterval.description: Network recovery interval in milliseconds (interval used when recovering from network failure)

requestedChannelMax.label: advanced
requestedChannelMax.description: Connection requested channel max (max number of channels offered)

requestedFrameMax.label: advanced
requestedFrameMax.description: Connection requested frame max (max size of frame offered)

requestedHeartbeat.label: advanced
requestedHeartbeat.description: Connection requested heartbeat (heart-beat in seconds offered)

requestTimeout.label: advanced
requestTimeout.description: Set timeout for waiting for a reply when using the InOut Exchange Pattern (in milliseconds)

synchronous.label: advanced
synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used, or Camel is allowed to use asynchronous processing (if supported).

topologyRecoveryEnabled.label: advanced
topologyRecoveryEnabled.description: Enables connection topology recovery (should topology recovery be performed)

transferException.label: advanced
transferException.description: When true and an inOut Exchange failed on the consumer side send the caused Exception back in the response

allowMessageBodySerialization.label: allowMessageBodySerialization
allowMessageBodySerialization.description: Whether to allow Java serialization of the message body or not. If this value is true, the message body will be serialized on the producer side using Java serialization, if no type converter can handle the message body. On the consumer side, it will deserialize the message body if this value is true and the message contains a CamelSerialize header. Setting this value to true may introduce a security vulnerability as it allows an attacker to attempt to deserialize to a gadget object which could result in a RCE or other security vulnerability.

sslProtocol.label: security
sslProtocol.description: Enables SSL on connection, accepted value are true, TLS and 'SSLv3

trustManager.label: security
trustManager.description: Configure SSL trust manager, SSL should be enabled for this option to be effective

username.label: security
username.description: Username in case of authenticated access
